div.l: ¶Her͗e beginneth þe Carpenters tale
Deth drew þe tappe of life and lete it goıı̄nne
And euer sith hath þe tap ronne
Til þat al moost empti is þe tonne
Þe streme of life now droppeth on þe chimbe
Þe seli tonge mai now ryng and clymbe
Of wrecchednesse þat passed is ful yore
With olde folk saue dotage is no more
When þat oure hoste had herd þis sermonyng
He began to speke as lordely as a kyng
He seid what amounteth al þis wit
What shuld we speke al day of holi writ
Þe deuel made a reue for to preche
Or a sowter a shipman or a leche
Sey forth þi tale and tari not þe tyme
Lo depford and it is half wey prime
Lo grenewiche þat many a shrew is yn
It wer͗e tyme þi tale to bigyn̄
Now ʆsires qduod þis Oswald the reue
I pray you all ye not you greue
Thogh I answer͗e and som dele set his howe
For leful is with fressh force eschewe
This dronkelndronkeldronken miller hath told vs her͗e
How þat bigiled was a Carpenter͗e
ꝐParauenture in scorne for I am oon̄
And be youre leue I shal quite it anone
Right on his cherles termes wil I speke
I prey to god his nek most breke
He can wel in myn̄ ey finde a stalk
But in his own̄ he can not se a balk
Here endeth the prolog of the Carpenters tale / And next
Biginneth þe Carpenters tale of the Miller of Trounpyngdoıı̄un
A Trumpingtoıı̄un not fer͗e fro Cantebrigge
Þere goth a broke and ouer þat a brigge
Vpon þe which broke þer͗e stonte a mylle
And þis is soth þat I you tell
A myller was þer͗e dwelling many a day
As any pocok he was stoute and gay
Pipe he coude fissh and net bete
And torne cuppes and wel wrastel and shete
And bi his belt he bar͗e a longe panade
And as a swerde ful trenchand was þe blade
A Ioli popper bare he in his pouche
Ther͗e was no man for ꝑperill durst hīm touch
